Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mutsun reclamation continued: Three years in a learner's efforts to acquire language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of California-Davis doctoral student Lajos Szoboszlai, under the guidance of Dr. Martha Macri, will investigate the processes and outcomes of adult language acquisition in the absence of a community of native speakers. The research will be conducted with an adult tribal member who is learning his ancestral language Mutsun, a Costanoan language traditionally spoken in Northern California, using a grammar, a dictionary, and a few pedagogical materials. Szoboszlai will identify how language accessed solely through these documentary materials influences what structures are learned, which are simplified, and which are modified by speakers. Since most of what is known about second language acquisition is based on learning in a classroom or through emersion in a robust speech community, the results of this project will provide brand new insights on the process of adult language acquisition.

Lajos Szoboszlai will employ qualitative analysis to conduct this longitudinal study. His database will consist of e-mails, semi-structured interviews, and 77 hours of audio-recordings of tutoring sessions with the tribal member. This data will be coded to allow for tracking of acquisition of particular grammatical forms. The many efforts underway by indigenous communities trying to revive the use of traditional languages offer an opportunity to investigate the learning process and the effects of this specific learning environment for language change.

The repurposing of language documentation materials as reflected in this project reflects the importance of high-quality language documentation for endangered language communities. It is only with such materials that worldwide linguistic diversity can be maintained and that communities can hope to regain use of their ancestral languages

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efforts are currently being made to preserve many of the world's less widely spoken languages. Languages with few or no speakers remaining, often as a result of colonial pressures, are also being revived. Individual learners often lead these efforts or participate independently. The process of learning a language with no native speakers to emulate, relying only on documentation, has not been systematically studied in an individual learner. The aim of this research project is to answer important questions about language acquisition in this context. Given the ongoing loss of speakership of many of the world's estimated 6000 languages, an exploration of this phenomenon is timely. It is increasingly likely that learners interested in reviving their ancestral tongues will have to do so without the benefit of fluent speakers, relying instead on documentation. This research will be useful to such learners, but will also investigate how it is possible to learn language in this way, something that was considered impossible before the success of Wampanoag revival in Massachusetts, for example, and other recent efforts.

            The current study followed a learner of Mutsun, a Costanoan language of central California, for four years as he engaged in language learning and developed a language program for other interested Mutsun learners. A number of questions were addressed though analysis of over 100 recordings of meetings between the learner and the researcher. The learner's goals and his ability to sustain his learning effort, the nature and use of existing materials as well as creation of new materials by the learner have been documented and analyzed. Approaches and methods used to learn the language, and an analysis of the learner's achievements, both in language learning and the advancement of Mutsun revival will further be explored and analyzed in the dissertation supported by this grant.

            Preliminary findings point to the usefulness of an integrated approach to language learning that is driven by the learner's goals. The researcher was a part of the learner's self directed learning (SDL) project acting as a linguistic resource helping the learner navigate the available documents, some of which, such as the Mutsun grammar, are incomprehensible to anyone without linguistic training. The researcher's additional roles as learning partner and adviser contributed to the learner's progress by validating his interests and supporting his desire to engage with the language for his own purposes rather than following an artificially imposed curriculum.

            Further results point to the difficulty of maintaining involvement with learning over a multi-year period; other responsibilities and engagements sometimes take precedence over language work for extended periods. Loss of resources and support causes a loss of engagement consistent with the prediction that an SDL project, since it is constructed by the learner, needs all its parts to function. The researcher's two extended absences during the project period both resulted in significantly limited progress, pointing to a strong need for a persistent working relationship to maintain learner engagement. On a more quotidian level, engagement was promoted by the pursuit of discrete and achievable goals such as translation of short introductory speeches and prayers to be used by the learner at tribal gatherings. Other achievable goals included teaching aspects of the language and acquiring the ability to have simple conversations.
